sentence: Then we now come to -LRB-e-RRB-, the management proposal to abolish Montgomery, Pennsylvania, a nonappropriated fund wage area, to which there was a Labor counter-proposal last time, and Management folks said Management folks needed more time to consider last time.

sentence: Should we review the specifics, or is there any response at this point from management?.

sentence: Mr.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: Chairman, MR.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: ALLEN think we need to decide on this, this one at this meeting today, because there is a wage survey that's scheduled for August, which is not such a big deal, as long as we have a recommendation from the committee on what to do with the employees, because there is currently no capability of conducting a local wage survey in that wage area.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: MR.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: ALLEN believe what the suggestion was from a member from NAGE at the last meeting was to move Chester County, Pennsylvania, into the Burlington wage area.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: We went back and looked at the regulatory criteria analysis that the Department of Defense had done through the DoD Wage Committee, and We really don't see any way that We could at OPM justify issuing a regulation to define Chester County to the Burlington wage area.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: When we look at the regulatory criteria, the first criterion is distance, and Chester County is almost twice as far away at least from the point we do the measurement from, from Burlington County as the measurement is from Harford County.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: MR.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: ALLEN also took a closer look at other wage areas surrounding, and the York wage area would actually be closer than the Burlington wage area.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: When I looked at the commuting patterns, commuting out of Chester County is actually less than a quarter of a percent to any of the surrounding NAF survey areas, so that to I is really a nonfactor.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: So MR.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: ALLEN think what we're really looking at is proximity, and MR.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: ALLEN think we really do need to stick with the concept that proximity is really what drives the need to define areas of application for nonappropriated fund wage areas.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: They're a little bit different than how we define the appropriated fund areas, because we have to define every county to the appropriated fund system, and the law was written a little differently for how nonappropriated fund wage areas are to be defined.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: That's about all That have on that one.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: Just so CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN understand, you're basically sticking with you's original proposal and not agreeing to the suggested change proposed by Labor?.
speaker: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN

sentence: We've taken a careful look at a careful look.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: We really don't see how We could justify.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: MR.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: ELDER do have a question.

sentence: At what point do you use to measure the proximity?.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: How do you measure that from Burlington County to Chester County?.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: It's measured from the location where the main employment location is, so It's measured from Coatesville, Pennsylvania, which is in Chester County.

sentence: That's the location of the VA medical center that's there.

sentence: If you look at a map, what you actually see is Philadelphia, the city and the suburbs of Philadelphia, east of Coatesville, and then there's a lot of rural area west of Coatesville.

sentence: So, MR.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: ELDER mean, it would seem, given what was proposed, the proposal was to move Philadelphia and Montgomery County into Burlington and retain New Castle in the Burlington area.

sentence: It would seem, just from looking at the map, Chester County is at least as close to Burlington as New Castle.

sentence: So it doesn't make sense to define Chester into a county to the west, to the southwest, with a smaller population than defining a county to the west into the larger population and larger area containing Philadelphia and Burlington.

sentence: It would seem to MR.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: ELDER this particular area should be defined into Burlington.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: MR.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: ELDER mean, if you're putting Philadelphia into this wage area, Philadelphia would seem to shift the center of the Burlington wage area, the center of their's employment, west toward Chester County, whereas before the center of the Burlington wage area , the center of their employment might have been further east in Burlington County.

sentence: What page is the map that you're referring to?.

sentence: It's a part of 564-MGT-3.

sentence: MR.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: Okay.

sentence: What the management proposal does is the management proposal looks at each county in the current Montgomery wage area, and the management proposal looks at the OPM regulatory criteria generally.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: The first criterion looked at is proximity, and MR.

sentence: ALLEN think the committee has agreed the committee's the primary criterion to look at.

sentence: The other criteria are actually kind of indeterminate, and the primary reason that the Management proposal recommends moving Chester County to the Harford wage area is proximity from the location where the employees work at the VA medical center in Chester county to the host installation for the Harford wage area, which is Aberdeen Proving Ground.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: Right.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: MR.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: ELDER mean, that still doesn't address the point that MR.

sentence: It should really be considered the center for the definition of the Burlington area, and Burlington would move Burlington closer to Chester County and move a larger number of employees, MR.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: ELDER'm sure, than are in the Harford area.
speaker: MR. ELDER

sentence: So that would further weight the distribution toward moving Chester into the Burlington wage area.

sentence: The center of that wage area actually shifts over to Burlington County, which is why the distances are measured from what would be each area of application county to the closest survey area, which is the reason why we're recommending that Chester County be part of the Harford wage area.

sentence: When we look at distance, MR.

sentence: ALLEN think it's something like 48 miles to Harford County and 78 miles to Burlington, so it's sort of skipping over Philadelphia because the labor market in Philadelphia for nonappropriated fund employment and the way that the wage schedule is determined, is actually no longer relevant to how pay is set in that wage area.

sentence: Philadelphia seems like an awfully strange place to just skip over, but for these purposes -- But what about New Castle County?.

sentence: MR.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: ALLEN'm not sure exactly when, but there was a recommendation from the committee to have it as part of the Burlington wage area, probably again based on distance primarily.

sentence: What happened after the conclusion of the working group -- this would have been in 2008 -- FPRAC had deferred most of the conclusion of the working group -- this would have been in 2008 -- FPRAC's business while the working group was taking place, and the working group could not come to consensus on one of five options that were mapped out on how to adjust the rules under which the committee would operate.

sentence: The main point of disagreement was on whether to use GS locality pay areas or not, and there was eventually a majority vote to use, MR.

sentence: If there was a county with more than 300 employees, then a county with more than 300 employees should be included in a survey area and that type of thing.

sentence: And MR.

sentence: Anyway, this was a letter that came from U.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: S.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Headquarters, Army Materiel Command.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: It is the higher headquarters for Tobyhanna Army Depot.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: It is a memorandum through Dr.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Susan Duncan, who is the AG-1 for Civilian Personnel, Army, to Chairman Friedman.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The subject is the impact of the application of locality pay to Federal Wage System employees.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The Federal Prevailing Rate advisory Committee has been discussing the application of locality pay to Federal Wage System -LRB-FWS-RRB- employees at locations where locality pay is given to General Schedule -LRB-GS-RRB- employees.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: This letter -- this is to express the concerns of the U.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: S.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Army Materiel Command -LRB-AMC-RRB- as to the significant impact this change would have on AMC.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: One AMC installation, Tobyhanna Army Depot, specifically exemplifies the financial impacts of the FPRAC decision.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In 2005, Monroe County, Pennsylvania, was placed in the New York locality pay area.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: A consequence of this decision was that GS employees at Tobyhanna Army Depot were added to the New York locality pay area.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Since that time, the American Federation of Government Employees Local 1647 has been advocating for New York locality pay for FWS employees.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In light of the Union's request before the FPRAC, we write to place on the record we's concerns about the impact of an FPRAC decision on the cost to operate Tobyhanna Army Depot.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Tobyhanna Army Depot is located in the northwest border of Monroe County, 22 miles from Scranton, Pennsylvania, and 101 miles form New York City, New York.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: While approximately 18 percent of residents in the eastern portion of Monroe County commute out of Monroe County to work, particularly in high-paying jobs in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan areas, the vast majority of Tobyhanna Army Depot's 4,250 employees reside outside of Monroe County.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Lackawanna County hosts 1,510 Tobyhanna Army Depot employees, and Luzerne County has 1,070 Tobyhanna Army Depot employees.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Both Lackawanna and Luzerne Counties lie in the Rest of the U.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: S.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: -LRB-RUS-RRB- for locality pay purposes.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Fewer than 600 Tobyhanna Army Depot employees reside in Monroe County.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Only 15 percent of the depot workforce resides in Monroe County and adjacent Pike County, which is also in the New York locality pay area.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: No Tobyhanna Army Depot employees commute from New York City to Tobyhanna,PA, and only seven Tobyhanna Army Depot employees live in New York State or New Jersey.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Commuting to Tobyhanna Army Depot does not appear to be a concern because Tobyhanna Army Depots location on the western border of Monroe County facilitates travel for the majority of the employees.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Most employees -LRB-60 percent-RRB- travel by interstate highway from Luzerne and Lackawanna Counties to Monroe County.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Public transportation is readily available to Tobyhanna Army Depot via van pool and bus.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Tobyhanna Army Depot has the largest Mass Transportation Benefit Program outside of the National Capital Region.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The average value of a Mass Transportation Benefit Program voucher per Tobyhanna Army Depot employee is $158 per quarter, or $632 annually.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Given that few -LRB-seven-RRB- employees commute from New York State or New Jersey to Tobyhanna Army Depot, the assumption that New York and New Jersey commuters living in Monroe County impact Tobyhanna Army Depot is false.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The mission of Tobyhanna Army Depot is to provide depot maintenance on weapons systems for the Department of Defense -LRB-DOD-RRB-.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Tobyhanna Army Depot is one of five maintenance depots under AMC Command, all of which are Army Working Capital Fund activities.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Accordingly, the Depot is not an appropriated activity but competes for the Depot's funding from other DoD customers that choose to have their's weapons systems repaired at Tobyhanna Army Depot.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Cost is a primary consideration in the decision to utilize Tobyhanna Army Depot as opposed to another maintenance provider in the DoD depot system or the private sector.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Consequently, Tobyhanna Army Depot strives to be the most efficient and cost-effective depot in the DoD.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Like Tobyhanna Army Depot, this Command is also concerned with costs.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The transfer of GS employees to the New York locality pay area in 2005 has already impacted Tobyhanna Army Depot's cost of operations and, consequently, the rate charged to DoD customers.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In Fiscal Year '10, for example, the New York locality pay was 28.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: 72 percent greater than the Rest of the United States -LRB-RUS-RRB-.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In this time of budget constraints, diminishing Federal resources, high unemployment, and the general condition of our's nation's economy, costs should be a factor in the committee's analysis.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Secretary of Defense Resource Management Directive 7032A eliminated approximately $834 million from the Army Operations and Maintenance Account -LRB-OMA-RRB-.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Accordingly, by memorandum dated 11 July 2011, the Army has directed the elimination of 8,741 full-time equivalents -LRB-FTEs or positions-RRB-.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The specific impact of the OMA reduction on weapon system support and maintenance has yet to be determined, but it is reasonable to conclude that depot maintenance programs will be cut or eliminated.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Unnecessary increases, such as those resulting from the AFGE proposal, will further impact AMC's ability to cost effectively maintain critical weapon systems.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: With respect to the need for New York locality pay at Tobyhanna Army Depot, the current average salary of a Tobyhanna Army Depot employee is $55,472.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The average salary for an FWS employee is $49,035 and $64,009 for a GS employee.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In 2010, the average salary of a private sector employee was $38,522 in Monroe County, $35,672 in Lackawanna County, and $36,137 in Luzerne County.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: According to the U.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: S.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Bureau of Labor Statistics annual report for the New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island-Eastern Pennsylvania Metropolitan Statistical Area, the average salary of a private sector employee in the New York locality pay area is $54,250.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The Cost of Living Index score for Monroe County is 95 in comparison to a score of 167 in New York City.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Thus, the overwhelming majority of employees at Tobyhanna Army Depot earn more than a private sector employee in either Monroe County or the New York locality pay area, while enjoying a substantially lower cost of living than a New York City resident.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The absence of FWS locality pay does not appear to have discouraged applicants for employment at Tobyhanna Army Depot.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Historically, Tobyhanna Army Depots attrition rate is low, 6 percent in 2011, and there is a well-qualified labor pool to fill vacancies.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In Fiscal Year 2010, for example, Tobyhanna received over 40,000 applications for employment.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: FWS salaries will increase by approximately 25 percent, the New York locality pay differential rate if this proposal is approved.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: For example, a Wage Grade-10, Step 3 employee was paid $21.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: 96 per hour in 2010 under the RUS locality pay adjustment.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: If Tobyhanna Army Depot was included in the New York locality pay, that Wage Grade-10 employee would receive $27.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: 53 per hour.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: The FY11 cumulative impact would be almost $27 million in increased salary costs to Tobyhanna Army Depot.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: This proposal would increase the cost to Tobyhanna Army Depot and This proposal's customers by approximately $130 million over a five-year period and would have a negative impact on the Depot's competitiveness and could actually force the Depot to release personnel.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In conclusion, the current methodology of defining locality pay boundaries is troublesome and inconsistent, and further study is needed of this issue.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Although it may generally seem logical to apply locality pay on a county-wide basis, the Tobyhanna Army Depot situation shows that this has resulted in a large salary disparity between public and private sector salaries.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In this era of fiscal austerity and dramatic budget cuts, the FPRAC should review current rules for applying locality pay, particularly where this era of fiscal austerity and dramatic budget cuts leads to the increase rates at Tobyhanna Army Depot and the potential for additional reductions in force.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: There needs to be a comprehensive nationwide pay-setting process that is truly equitable, representative, and considers the financial impact of the decision.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: A more clearly defined process would both reduce the cost of government and restore balance and fairness to pay setting for all Federal employees.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Further, the financial and staffing impacts of any decision, to include the potential loss of workload and personnel, must be considered.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: In light of these concerns, AMC recommends that the FPRAC -LRB-1-RRB- refuse to extend the locality pay decision to FWS employees and -LRB-2-RRB- revisit the validity of the 2005 decision applying New York locality pay to Tobyhanna Army Depot's GS employees.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Thank you for providing us with an opportunity to comment on this matter of extreme importance.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN

sentence: If not, please thank Mr.
speaker: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN

sentence: Marriott for providing this input to our's committee.
speaker: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN

sentence: MS.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: WALKER will do that.
speaker: MS. WALKER

speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: WALKER have a couple of other comments, and this is something that has really confused MS.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: WALKER since this whole matter was kind of brought before the FPRAC.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: MS.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: WALKER still don't understand the genesis and the justification for the linking of the FWS pay to the GS locality pay to begin with.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Is there a way that we could get the history of a way since a way seems to be kind of at the crux of this whole issue?.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Because that didn't happen until, what, 2004, 2005?.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: But prior to that, the FWS salary was in no way linked to the GS locality pay.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: I guess what Barbara is talking about is the floor increase provision.
speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: That's what That assumed she was talking about.
speaker: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN

speaker: MR. ALLEN

speaker: MR. ALLEN

speaker: MR. ALLEN

sentence: MS.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: WALKER think that that's something that if that all understand what the genesis of that was, maybe the genesis of that will shed some light on the validity of making any changes.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Also, as you heard in the letter, Tobyhanna is very concerned about the fact that the GS locality area was moved to the New York area.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: It's been very costly to Army.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: Army has paid the biggest bill due to these changes, and we don't understand how these changes happened either, because DoD nor Army was a part of the Federal Salary Council that even made that decision.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: And MS.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: WALKER realize that GS pay is not what we do here on the FPRAC committee --.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: That's correct.
speaker: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN

sentence: -- but it does impact what we have on the floor in front of we right now to decide.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: So, if we could possibly get -- and MS.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: WALKER'm assuming that that information is open to the public, since public funds are paying the bill -- how we came to that decision, the GS employees from Monroe County to New York?.
speaker: MS. WALKER

sentence: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN believe if you consult the reports of the Federal Salary Council for whatever the relevant year is, CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN guess the relevant year would be 2004, something like the Federal Salary Council.
speaker: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN

sentence: That would have the rationale, and That believe the rationale was based on commuting patterns at the time.

speaker: MS. SIMON

sentence: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN did, indeed.
speaker: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN

sentence: Well, that's the answer to your's question, because your question's based on Census data, and the Decennial Census of 2000 had commuting data, and that brought Monroe County into the -- is Monroe County the combined statistical area or the metropolitan statistical area that includes New York City?.
speaker: MS. SIMON

sentence: CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN don't mean to cut you off in any way, but you can certainly get you's question answered by top experts at OPM right around the table here, Jerry and Mark, who can give you all the history of the Federal Salary Council, and the Federal Salary Council would be the correct body, CHAIRMAN FRIEDMAN think, not this one, for any questions about how Monroe County came to be redefined to the New York GS locality pay area.

sentence: Increasing the salaries will basically cost us twice as much money, because us will be paying the salaries as well as paying higher cost for the work that's done at Tobyhanna, so twice as much money's going to be a bigger financial impact on the Department of Defense.
